speaker: Paul Noble
text: All right. Now, if "I have decorated the house" is-

speaker: Marion
text: J'ai décoré la maison.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: How do you think I, you would say, "I decorated the house"?

speaker: Marion
text: J'ai décoré la maison.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Now, you may have guessed correctly that actually in French, "I have decorated the house," and, "I decorated the house," are in fact said in exactly the same way.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: In English, we use two different tenses there. We have, "I have decorated the house." We also have, "I decorated the house." There's a slight difference in meaning in English. It's very small, but it does exist. But in French, it's in fact easier because both for, "I have decorated the house," or, "I decorated the house," for both of them, you will simply say?

speaker: Marion
text: J'ai décoré la maison.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Okay. If, "I have decorated the house," and, "I decorated the house," is?

speaker: Marion
text: J'ai décoré la maison.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: How do you think you would say, "I did decorate the house?"

speaker: Marion
text: J'ai décoré la maison.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: As you can see, for all three tenses that we have in English, just one is used in French. And this is one way in which French is much easier to learn than English.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Um, you may, if you know French people, or if you've spent time in a French-speaking country, you may find that they sometimes use English in a way we wouldn't. They may say something like, um,

speaker: Paul Noble
text: uh, "I have decorated the house last night," which we wouldn't say. We'd say, "I decorated the house last night." It's difficult for them to understand that in English we will use very variable tenses for this same type of expression. Because in French, they will, for all of them, they'll just be saying, "I have decorated the house." So, it's a problem for French speakers. But fortunately for us, for English speakers, it's an advantage, because you don't need to worry about swapping tenses. Everything is, "I have decorated the house." "I have this", "I have that". Um, as we'll now see.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: All right. How would you say, "You have decorated the house?"

speaker: Marion
text: Vous avez décoré la maison.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Let's turn that round into a question now, and we're going to change, "You have," round into, "Have you?" And we're going to say, "Have you decorated the house?"

speaker: Marion
text: Avez-vous décoré la maison?

speaker: Paul Noble
text: How do you think you'd pronounce the French word, "reservation"?

speaker: Marion
text: Réservation.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: And how do you think you'd change it and make it into "reserved"? You'll cut off the "-ation" and add the "café E". So what will "reserved" be?

speaker: Marion
text: Réservé.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: How would you say, "He has reserved"?

speaker: Marion
text: Il a réservé.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Um, "a table" in French, "a table" is?

speaker: Marion
text: Une table.

speaker: Marion
text: Une table.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: So how would you say, "He has reserved a table?"

speaker: Marion
text: Il a réservé une table.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Again, "table" is spelt the same way in English as it is in French, and you'll find that words in English that end in A-B-L-E, as well as perhaps you can call them their cousins, words that end in I-B-L-E in English,

speaker: Paul Noble
text: are the same in French. So you'll find these words that end in A-B-L-E or I-B-L-E, and so A-B-L-E such as "table" for instance, it will be the same word normally in French, pronounced differently. But if you can learn French pronunciation, it gives you access to thousands of words simply using the English you already know.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Okay. So if, "he has reserved a table" is?

speaker: Marion
text: Il a réservé une table.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: How would you say, "He reserved a table?"

speaker: Marion
text: Il a réservé une table.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: As you can see, again, it's the same. 'Cause where we would use two tenses, they use one. Let's try the same thing again. How would you say, "He did reserve a table?"

speaker: Marion
text: Il a réservé une table.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: As you may remember, "your father" in French is?

speaker: Marion
text: Votre père.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: How would you say, "Your father has reserved a table?"

speaker: Marion
text: Votre père a réservé une table.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: "For you" in French is?

speaker: Marion
text: Pour vous.

speaker: Marion
text: Pour vous.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: How would you say, "I have reserved a table for you?"

speaker: Marion
text: J'ai réservé une table pour vous.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: To say, "For dinner," in French as we mentioned earlier, you'll say, "For the dinner." Can you remember what that is?

speaker: Marion
text: Pour le dîner.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Again, make sure to pronounce "the dinner" as?

speaker: Marion
text: Le dîner.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: So with that in mind, how would you say, "I have reserved a table for dinner." Whereas the French would say, "I have reserved a table for the dinner."

speaker: Marion
text: J'ai réservé une table pour le dîner.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Let's look again at the word, "invitation", which was a little bit trickier to pronounce because the, the "in-" at the beginning has that sort of sulky teenager sound that's pronounced.

speaker: Marion
text: Un.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: So how would you say again, "invitation"?

speaker: Marion
text: Invitation.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Okay, and let's change the "invitation" into "invited". We'll cut off the "-ation" and add a "café E". So, "invited" will be?

speaker: Marion
text: Invité.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: So how would you say, "I have invited"?

speaker: Marion
text: J'ai invité.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: How would you say, "I have invited Paul"?

speaker: Marion
text: J'ai invité Paul.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: To say, "To the park," in French, "to the park", you'll say?

speaker: Marion
text: Au parc.

speaker: Marion
text: Au parc.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: So how would you say, "I have invited Paul to the park"?

speaker: Marion
text: J'ai invité Paul au parc.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: To say, "To the cinema," you would say?

speaker: Marion
text: Au cinéma. Au cinéma.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: So how would you say, "Have you invited Paul to the cinema?"

speaker: Marion
text: Avez-vous invité Paul au cinéma?
